newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa 96/97 revenue collection on track - Manuel.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa 96/97 revenue collection on track - Manuel.

text.p: Revenue collection for 1996/97 was "perfectly on track" to achieve the targeted reduction in the budget deficit to 5.1 percent, Finance Minister Trevor Manuel said.
He said on Tuesday 900 million rand in arrear taxes had already been collected.
Tax collection was improving and legislation outlining the South African Revenue Services' (SARS) autonomy would be tabled in the first quarter of 1997, he said.

Briefing the parliamentary public accounts committee, Manuel said negotiations were still underway but he was optimistic the legislation would provide the SARS with enough autonomy to become a performance driven entity.
"We have a few feathers in our collective cap on the negotiations already but I would not like to say more at this stage," Manuel said.
Over the past 12 months, SARS had been formed, unifying inland revenue and customs and excise departments.
He said SARS would be funded by receiving a certain percentage of revenue collected and this would be used to help provide incentive schemes to staff in the new fiscal year.
As soon as it had finalised its business plan, SARS would receive the extra 150 million rand allocated to revenue collection by the budget in the current financial year.
